definition: W is the twenty-third letter of the English alphabet
for west
for Western Australia
A wad of something is a lump of it that has been packed tightly together.
example: He stopped the bleeding with a wad of cottonwool. [j33] The old sailor was chewing on a wad of tobacco

definition: If someone waddles, they walk like a duck, taking short steps and swaying from side to side

senses.definition: ' If you wade through water, you walk through it and it reaches your knees or higher up your body.
example: We waded across the ford. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you wade through something, you get through it slowly and with difficulty.  [cf2]I'm still wading through the consultants' report

definition: A wafer is a thin crisp biscuit

senses.definition: ' In informal language, if you say a student wags school, you mean that they don't go there although they're supposed to.
example: He was in terrible trouble when his parents found out he'd been wagging classes

senses.definition: ' A wage is the money that someone, especially a labourer or a factory worker, earns in a regular job.  Sometimes this word is used in the plural, wages, with the same meaning.
example: He didn't feel he could get married until he was earning a good wage. [j33] I have to spend nearly half my wages on rent
' In formal language, if you say that a country wages war, you mean that it fights a war

senses.definition: ' can't wait'  In informal language, if you say you can't wait to do something, you mean that you are very excited about it and looking forward to doing it.

senses.definition: ' walk out'  If you walk out, you leave suddenly because you are offended or angry.
example: Sometimes I leave the car at home and walk to work. [j33] I really enjoy walking in the bush. [j33] He opened the door and walked into the room. [j33] Sarah's baby's just learning to walk
Let's go for a walk by the river
I'd recognise Don's walk anywhere
She said if they spoke to her like that she'd walk out

example: The thieves had climbed over the back wall. [j33] I sat on the garden wall and watched them work

They were caught painting graffiti on the walls of the school. [j33] We knocked down the wall between the lounge and the kitchen. 3 ' drive up the wall'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say someone drives you up the wall, you mean that they irritate you.  They make you feel impatient with them.  [cf2]Hari drives me up the wall with his endless chatter. [j33] This stupid computer program is driving me up the wall[j4]I just can't make it do what I want

senses.definition: ' ward off'  If you ward something off, you manage to keep it away from you or prevent it from happening.
example: ...the children's ward. [j33] ...the maternity ward
We have to vote for two councillors out of the six candidates for our ward
He made Julia his ward, and paid for her education. [j33] When their marriage broke up, the youngest three children became wards
He warded off the dog with his umbrella. [j33] I think I'm getting a cold, but I'm taking vitamins to ward it off. [j33] We hope that these new businesses will ward off the threat of retrenchments

senses.definition: ' warm up'   (a) If you warm food up, you heat it so that it is ready to eat. Usually it has already been cooked.
example: HAND WASH IN WARM WATER [j33] It's a warm spring day. [j33] The sea is quite warm already. [j33] They brought us warm rolls and butter. [j33] The paper is still warm from the photocopier

Are you warm enough, or would you like the fire on? [j33] You're not going to be very warm in that flimsy dress. [j33] It's important to keep warm when you've got a cold. 3 ' '[cf2]adjective If clothes are warm, they keep you from feeling cold because they are thick and cover your body.  [cf2]Bring warm clothes[j4]it's snowing in the mountains. [j33] This blanket's too warm for the summer
Jane's very warm and welcoming, unlike her husband. [j33] He gave me a warm smile
I turned on the electric blanket to warm the bed. [j33] Come in and warm yourself by the fire
I didn't exactly warm to Elsie when I first met her. [j33] He was very quiet, but as I got to know him I gradually warmed to him

There's soup for lunch[j4]I just have to warm it up. [j33] I'll put the leftovers in the fridge[j4]we can warm them up tomorrow. [j33] Will you eat the quiche cold or shall I warm it up? '   (b) '[cf2] In sport, if you warm up before a race or match, you prepare for it by doing exercises just before it starts
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb warmly' She smiled warmly and said hello.[j35]'noun warmth'

Are you warm enough, or would you like the fire on? [j33] You're not going to be very warm in that flimsy dress. [j33] It's important to keep warm when you've got a cold. 3 ' '[cf2]adjective If clothes are warm, they keep you from feeling cold because they are thick and cover your body.  [cf2]Bring warm clothes[j4]it's snowing in the mountains. [j33] This blanket's too warm for the summer
Jane's very warm and welcoming, unlike her husband. [j33] He gave me a warm smile
I turned on the electric blanket to warm the bed. [j33] Come in and warm yourself by the fire
I didn't exactly warm to Elsie when I first met her. [j33] He was very quiet, but as I got to know him I gradually warmed to him

There's soup for lunch[j4]I just have to warm it up. [j33] I'll put the leftovers in the fridge[j4]we can warm them up tomorrow. [j33] Will you eat the quiche cold or shall I warm it up? '   (b) '[cf2] In sport, if you warm up before a race or match, you prepare for it by doing exercises just before it starts
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb warmly' She smiled warmly and said hello.[j35]'noun warmth'

senses.definition: ' If you warn someone, you tell them about possible problems or dangers.
example: He warned us that the road might be flooded. [j33] It's not an easy task[j4]don't say I didn't warn you. [j33] You'll be in big trouble if you stuff it up, let me warn you! 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you warn someone not to do something, you advise them not to do it or order them not to do it.  [cf2]A $130 fine[j4]I warned you not to break the speed limit! [j33] She warned the children not to speak to strangers. [j33] He warned me not to touch anything on his desk while he was away
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See warning'.

definition: A warning tells people, in spoken words or in writing, that a dangerous or unpleasant thing might happen.
example: The weather bureau has issued a warning that a cyclone is approaching. [j33] Lionel ignored my warnings and set off

definition: If something warps, it loses its shape and becomes bent or curved.
example: Your tennis racquet will warp if you leave it outside

definition: If you say someone is warped, you mean that they have a bitter, distorted view of life.
example: These sick jokes appealed to her warped sense of humour

senses.definition: ' In formal language, if you say something warrants a certain course of action, you mean it makes it necessary or appropriate.
example: A police officer who comes onto your property or searches your possessions without a warrant and against your wishes may be guilty of trespass
The doctors feel that young Ari's symptoms warrant further investi~ gation. [j33] His minor breach of etiquette didn't warrant the torrent of abuse he received

definition: A warranty on a product is a legal recognition of liability.
example: There is a twelve-month warranty on all our appliances

definition: A wart is a small raised lump, caused by a virus, which can appear on your skin
If you are wary about some~ thing, you are very cautious in the way that you approach it.
example: I'm a bit wary about Jim's tips on the races[j4]last time I lost $500. [j33] I'm wary of getting too involved in her problems. [j33] I'd be wary if I were you[j4]the deal seems too good to be true

definition: Was is the first and third person singular form of the past tense of be

senses.definition: ' wash your hands of'  If you say you wash your hands of something, you mean that you accept no further responsibility for it.
example: I've just washed my hair. [j33] Wash your hands before dinner. [j33] The dye ran when I washed my T-shirt. [j33] He paid the boys to wash the car. [j33] You should wash the wall before you paint it
Just give me half an hour to wash and change, and I'll be ready. [j33] You need to wash more frequently in the hot weather
During the storm a lot of soil was washed onto the path. [j33] I washed the spider down the plughole
Where's my blue shirt?  It must be in the wash
I managed to wash out the grease on the collar. '   (b) '[cf2] If an event is washed out, it is cancelled because of rain.  [cf2]The match was washed out for the second week running
I'll cook and you can wash up
I've given them my advice, but they won't listen[j4]I wash my hands of the whole project. [j33] He's your son[j4]you can't just wash your hands of him
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun wash' These curtains need a wash.[j35]'adjective washable' Is this blouse washable silk, or does it need to be dry-cleaned?[j35]'noun washing' I hung the washing out to dry.  I put my shirt in with the dirty washing.

senses.definition: ' waste away'  If someone wastes away, they get thinner and thinner.
example: Don't waste water by leaving the tap running. [j33] They wasted their money on trashy souvenirs. [j33] We've wasted too much time already
He might have got the job if he'd tried harder, but he wasted the opportunity
Don't waste the good wine on Joe[j4]he doesn't know the difference. [j33] The irony was wasted on her, as she didn't know what he was talking about
We try to recycle as much of our waste as possible. [j33] They discovered rusting cans of toxic waste on the site
Take the cakes home with you or they'll go to waste
Once he got sick he wasted away before our eyes
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun waste' It's a waste of time arguing.  I was shocked at the waste of resources.[j35] 'adjective waste' ...a waste product.  I threw out a huge pile of waste paper when I moved office.[j35] 'adjective wasteful' Don't be so wasteful with the detergent.

senses.definition: ' watch out for'  If you watch out for something, you remain alert in case you see it.
example: The kids are watching television as usual. [j33] We watched the parade go past. [j33] Watch how I fold the sheets. [j33] John's playing football on Saturday and we're all going along to watch
Could you watch Laura while I go to the shops? [j33] Police watched the suspect for weeks before they arrested him. [j33] We are aware of the situation and are watching developments
Watch how you handle that knife[j4]it's very sharp. [j33] Watch you don't stay too late and miss the last bus. [j33] You need to watch your step on the slippery floor
My watch has stopped. [j33] What time does your watch say? [j33] He looked impatiently at his watch
Two of the soldiers slept while the third kept watch. [j33] The dog kept watch over his body until the rescuers arrived
In this area you have to watch out for snakes. [j33] Watch out for Sammy[j4]he should be arriving any minute now. [j33] I've been watching out for a blue pleated skirt for a while

senses.definition: (b)' If you water something down, you make it weaker.
example: I drank two glasses of water straight down. [j33] Cook the pasta in boiling water for ten minutes
' If you water a garden, you pour water on it to help the plants grow
He spent money like water after he won the lottery, and soon it was all gone
The weed killer needs to be watered down before you spray the garden
The proposed legislation has been severely watered down during its passage through parliament
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective watery' This soup is rather watery.

senses.definition: 2' word for word'  If you repeat or quote something word for word, you use the exact words in which it was originally expressed.

I give you my word it won't happen again. [j33] He kept his word. [j33] He was as good as his word. [j33] He broke his word. [j33] He went back on his word

I've been meaning to have a word with you about how things are going
It was a difficult meeting[j4] Julie and Don had words about the budget
He is arrogant, mean and selfish[j4]in a word, a total bastard

He accused me in so many words of being a liar. [j33] She told the boss in so many words that he should mind his own business when it comes to her private life.  11 ' the last word'   (a) '[cf2] If you have the last word in a discussion or argument, you have the final or decisive say. '   (b) '[cf2] If you say something is the last word in something, you mean that it has that quality to a very high degree. [cf2]Her unit is the last word in elegant design. This thankyou letter is word for word the same as last year! [j33] I can't remember it word for word, but it's something like 'By channels of coolness the echoes are calling'

definition: A workbench is a heavy table or a hard surface that people work on with tools
Workforce refers to all the people in a particular country, area or industry who are employed.
example: Working mothers form an increasing part of Australia's workforce

definition: Your workload is the amount of work that you have to do.
example: The sales department are complaining about their workload. [j33] I've got a pretty heavy workload over the next couple of weeks

definition: A workout is a time when you do physical exercise in order to improve your physical fitness.
example: Ron does a vigorous workout at the gym twice a week

definition: A workplace' is somewhere where people work.
example: ...a course in English for the workplace

definition: A workshop is a room or place with tools and machinery for making or repairing things

senses.definition: ' think the world of'  If you think the world of someone, you like and admire them very much.
example: I bought a ticket to fly round the world. [j33] I love to travel and see the world. [j33] People visit Australia from all over the world. [j33] Environmental campaigners want to save the world
He's an important figure in the literary world. [j33] I was keen to get out of the business world. [j33] The scandal shocked the racing world. [j33] We come from different worlds, but we get on
Jenna was on top of the world when she heard she'd got the job
Her singing was out of this world
My son thinks the world of his teacher
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective world' We went on a world tour.  He's the world champion.  ...a new world record.

senses.definition: ' can of worms'  If you say an issue is a can of worms, you mean that it's very complicated and difficult.  It is easier not to get involved with it.
example: The worms come to the surface after it rains
There was a worm in the apple
He didn't even have the grace to apologise, the miserable worm
I wormed through a hole in the fence. [j33] The baby wormed across the carpet. [j33] He wormed his way into her affections

I mentioned the question of subsidies, but he warned me to leave that can of worms alone. 6 ' worm out of'  '[cf2] If you worm something out of someone, you manage to get them to tell you what you want to know even though they are reluctant. [cf2]She just sat there sobbing, but I eventually wormed out of her what the problem was. [j33] She wormed the secret out of him by expressing concern

senses.definition: ' worse than useless'  If you say something is worse than useless, you mean that it is of no use at all.
example: My cold is getting worse. [j33] The first half of the concert was fairly boring, but the second half was worse
The walkers were found early the next morning, none the worse for their night in the bush
After all our efforts we were worse off than when we started
Sam's attempts to get us going again were worse than useless
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb worsen' The weather worsened, so we decided to turn back.

senses.definition: ' In formal language, the worth of something or someone is its value or importance.
example: Her diamond ring is worth $2000. [j33] It's only jade, but it's worth a lot to me because of its sentimental value
If you like history the museum is worth a visit. [j33] Is this old coat worth cleaning? [j33] It's not worth going so far for a week. [j33] It's worth keeping a copy in case the original gets lost
He bought $20 worth of chocolate. [j33] The vandals did $50 000 worth of damage. [j33] Three years worth of work went up in the blaze. [j33] She's got 15 years worth of records filed away
He was asked to estimate the worth of the vase. [j33] The incident proved the worth of his training. [j33] It's hard to cling on to your sense of worth when you're unemployed
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective worthless' It was a worthless fake.  Your promises are worthless to me.
